Award.AwardTitle: NUE: Using Peer-to-Peer Support to build NEMS and Consider SEEE Implications of Nanotechnology

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this Nanotechnology Undergraduate Education (NUE) in Engineering program at the University of California-Santa Barbara (UCSB) entitled "NUE: Using Peer-to-Peer Support to build NEMS and Consider SEE Implications of Nanotechnology", under the direction of Dr. Sumita Pennathur, is to prepare a new generation of well-rounded and educated engineers who are skilled in using cutting-edge nanofabrication tools and processes to build nanoscale systems (such as NEMS) and nanoscale devices. To do this a set of three new courses and a modification to an existing course will be developed. Two of the courses will increase a UCSB undergraduate's ability to build nanoscale devices and systems (NEMS), and the third, a new course will focus on their communication skills. Also proposed to be implemented is a high school education program that pairs high school students with undergraduate mentors who are enrolled in the NEMS class to enhance the communication skills of UCSB engineers.

The UCSB program will accelerate advances in nanotechnology via educational pathways across a broad range of sciences. Intensive, hands-on training in nanofabrication techniques building NEMS and through research experiences will prepare engineers for this exciting field.

The major goal of this project is to address the growing demand for a workforce skilled in nanofabrication techniques by educating and training undergraduates—especially females and minorities—in nanoscale science, nanofabrication processes, and the societal, ethical, economical, and environmental implications of nanotechnology.  To do so, we have (1) developed and taught a high-quality courses and provide lab experiences in nanoscale science and nanotechnology that will excite underrepresented students to pursue careers in this field, (2) enhanced student communication skills while exposing them to the widest range of topical areas in nanoscale science and technology—including the societal, ethical, economical, and environmental implications of nanotechnology, (3) exposed K-12 teachers to nanofabrication techniques through the NSF RET (research experience for teachers) program, and fostered a mentorship community between engineering-track undergraduates and junior high and high school students through hands-on laboratory experiences and interaction with undergraduate students through an innovative learning based software, Meemli.

 

         Specifically, we obtained new equipment towards the development of a new micro- and nanofabrication class to train new students. These lab improvements are shown in Figure "New Equipment Purchased". Next,  we developed two new courses, ME141A and ME141B, one which was based of an undergraduate textbook that was authored by the PI, Introduction to Nanotechnology. The second class used the above equipment to train student on the art of MEMS fabrication, where the students learned oxidation, lithography, etching, deposition, and built their own microfluidic cell sorter based on dielectrophoresis. They used all the equipment and were able to build successful devices.  For this grant, 5 classes were taught. We also successfully implemented the FFEWSE program (See Figure "FFEWSE Program"). Fluidics Fabrication Engineering Workshop in Secondary Education (FFEWSE) recognizes K-12 education as an opportunity to foster creative and innovative thinking within a scientific and engineering context and inspire students to consider careers in science and engineering. While focused on secondary education, we provide a framework for introducing nanotechnology within K-12 classrooms. Considering nanotechnology's increasing prevalence and relevance, such efforts are paramount if we, as a nation, desire to continue to compete globally as technical developers and scientific innovators.

Our fall program consisted of a two-part, four-day workshop. On day one, we presented the concept of Reynolds number, viscosity, and turbulent and laminar flows. For this program, we developed a system comprising of  a macrofluidic Y- channel made from milled transparent cast acrylic and a set of reservoirs which supplied colored water to the channel's ports. We demonstrated both turbulent and laminar regimes in the macrofluidic Y-channel by varying the fluid velocity in the device (Figure "Laminar Flow Demonstration and Fabrication Process"). Students completed homework based on lecture material. We also developed a method for fabricating microfluidic channels using hand-cut thin-film PDMS.
